questions.text:
Following an RTA, a patient develops Type Illa compound tibial fracture, arrange the external fixators in terms of stability (lowest to highest)
1. Ilizarov
2. Uniplanar with single rod
3. Uniplanar with double rod
4. Biplanar
questions.solution:
• Device which stabilises the bone from outside the body
  • Consists of:
    • Schanz pins
    • Connecting rods

How to improve the stability of external fixator?

  • Construct
    • Multiplanar
  • Pins
    • More pins
    • Widely spaced pins
    • Thicker pins
    • Multi directional
  • Rods
    • More rods
  • Ring External fixator (ILIZAROV – most stable)

Ilizarov has highest stability as it provides 360 degree stability


Sequence of stability from highest to lowest ilizarov> Uniplanar with double rod> Uniplanar with single rod>biplanar.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 7thedition page no 19.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a Tibial fracture on cast presents to emergency department with complaints of intense pain. Cast was removed and on examination Passive flexion was painful, dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are present and loss of sensation over the first web space was noted. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Based on clinical history patient is suffering from compartment syndrome ,so first we should confirm our diagnosis by measuring anterior compartment pressure. An intracompartment pressure above 30mm Hg is diagnostic of compartment syndrome.


Diagnosis of compartment syndrome

  • Normotensive patient
    • Compartment pressure >30 mmHg
  • Hypotensive patient
    • Delta P (diastolic BP - compartment pressure) <30mmHg

This patient has clinical symptoms and signs of leg compartment syndrome and should undergo immediate fasciotomies of all 4 leg compartments, followed by external fixation for fracture stabilization.

Tibial fractures are among the most common reasons for compartment syndromes of the leg. A clinical assessment is key in the diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome. If there is uncertainty, intracompartmental pressure measurement has been advocated to help confirm the diagnosis.

5 p's of compartment syndrome

  • pain out of proportion to exam,
  • paralysis
  • Paresthesias
  • Pallor
  • pulselessness

Pain on passive stretch - is the earliest sign

We can not perform intramedullary nailing or open reduction and internal fixation in this case because surgery itself is a predisposing factor for development of compartment syndrome

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 7thedition page number 47.

questions.text:
Following a femur shaft fracture, your consultant asks you to provide Tibial skeletal traction. Which of the following will you request from the nurse to do the same?
1. Thomas splint
2. K-wire
3. Steinman's pin
4. Denham's pin
5. Bohler's stirrup
6. Bohler brown splint / Frame
questions.solution:
UPPER TIBIAL TRACTION

  • Indication:
    • Fracture shaft of femur
  • Site of entry
    • 2cm distal and posterior to tibial tuberosity
  • Direction of pin:
    • Lateral to medial

As shown in above image for shaft femur fracture we will require

  • Steinman's pin
  • Bohler's stirrup
  • Bohler Braun splint.
  • Steinman pin is the pin driven into the tibia, Bohler stirrup is the device used to connect the Steinmann pin to the pulley and the Bohler Braun splint is the device to rest the leg on.

Reference:Fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra and jain 1stedition page no 23.

questions.text: Match the following with the best mode of management.
questions.solution:
• Simple bone cyst treatment:- Treatment: The cyst is known to undergo spontaneous healing, particularly after a fracture. One or two injections of methylprednisolone into the cyst results in healing. Some cases need curettage and bone grafting.
  • Osteosarcoma requires wide excision of mass or amputation.
  • Giant cell tumor treatment- Excision or Extended curettage : This is the treatment of choice when the tumour affects a bone whose removal does not hamper with functions e.g., the fibula, lower-end of the ulna etc.
  • Osteoid osteoma treatment:- Treatment: Complete excision of the nidus along with the sclerotic bone is done. Radiofrequency ablation is also used. Prognosis is good. It is not a pre-malignant condition.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 7thedition page no 232

questions.text: If the outer sheath and nerve fibre is intact and the inner axon are damaged, it is known as
questions.solution:
Seddon's classification: Seddon classifies nerve injuries into three types:

  1. neurapraxia;
  2. axonotmesis; and
  3. neurotmesis.

Neurapraxia: It is a physiological disruption of conduction in the nerve fibre. No structural changes occur. Recovery occurs spontaneously within a few weeks, and is complete.best prognosis. Eg- Saturday night palsy, crutch palsy, tourniquet palsy etc.

Axonotmesis: The axons are damaged but atleast one of the outer coverings of nerve intact. . Wallerian degeneration occurs. Recovery may occur spontaneously but may take many months. Complete recovery may not occur. Neuroma in continuity (progressive tinel's sign present). Rate of regeneration - 1mm/day. Motor march is seen.

Neurotmesis: The structure of a nerve is damaged by actual cutting or scarring of a segment. Wallerian degeneration occurs. Spontaneous recovery is not possible, and nerve repair is required. End neuroma, non progressive tinel's sign, motor march is absent. Worst prognosis

Reference: CAMPBELL OPERATIVE ORTHOPEDICS 14THEDITION PAGE NO 3277+ROCKWOOD AND GREENS FRACTURE IN ADULTS 9THEDITION PAGE NO 1136.

questions.text: Which nerve injury causes this?
questions.solution:
Clinical image shows clawing of only ring finger and little finger. Which is suggestive of ulnar nerve palsy.

ULNAR CLAW HAND DEFORMITY

  • Paralysis of 3rd, 4th lumbricals
  • Overaction of EDC and FDP
  • Intrinsic minus deformity
  • Mein en Griffe
  • Partial claw hand- isolated ulnar nerve injury
  • Complete claw hand: ulnar nerve + median nerve injury

Condition Features

Median Nerve Palsy (Labourer Nerve Palsy):

  • Pointing index
  • Pen test
  • Ape thumb deformity
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome

Ulnar Nerve Palsy Musician nerve palsy:

  • Book test (froment sign)
  • Card test
  • Egawa's test
  • Claw finger deformity

Radial Nerve Palsy:

  • Wrist drop

Erb's palsy: Policeman tip deformity (Porter's tip deformity)

Reference:Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics, 7th ed. pg. 64

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with history of Colle's fracture 8 months ago, attained menopause at the age of 52, comes with a T score of -2.5 on DEXA Scan, she is currently asymptomatic. What treatment that you will give her?
questions.solution:
Here T score of -2.5 on DEXA scan is diagnostic of osteoporosis.

What is T-score?

The T-score is the relevant measure when screening for osteoporosis. It is the bone mineral density (BMD. at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient's BMD to that of a healthy thirty-year-old.

The criteria of the World Health Organization are:

  • Normal is a T-score of -1.0 or higher
  • Osteopenia is defined as between -1.0 and -2.5
  • Osteoporosis is defined as -2.5 or lower. meaning a bone density that is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a thirty-year-old man/woman

Osteoporosis can cause back pain, deformities and high chance of fractures. Hence it is important to treat osteoporosis.

The drug of choice of osteoporosis is bisphosphonates such as Alendronate.

Problems of using bisphophonates:

  • Prolong fracture healing
  • Chronic use causes atypical fractures (subtrochanteric fractures of femur)
    • Prevention: by giving drug holiday (bisphosphiantes stopped after 5yr use and restarted after 2-3yrs bridged with teriperatide in absence of bisphophonates)

Supplements used in osteoporosis:

  • Calcium-800-1200mg/day
  • Vitamin D- 400-800 IU/day

Calcitonin (nasal spray)- 200-400 IU/day (mainly used for pain relief

Reference:Essential orthopedics Maheshwari 7thedition page no 309.

questions.text:
Which of the following are observed while performing Thomas's Test?
1. Squaring of pelvis
2. Flexion of hip
3. Over correction of normal side
4. Check lumbar lordosis
5. Measure the actual flexion deformity
6. Ensure the ischial tuberosity touches the couch
questions.solution:
As we can see in image how to perform Thomas test

Thomas test:-

  • Patient is positioned supine on a firm bed and then asked to flex the normal hip to bring the knee of normal side to his chest.
  • He is then asked to hold the normal limb in this position with hands. this automatically brings the diseased hip (hip with fixed flexion deformity) into some flexion. the examiner then passively lowers the affected limb to the bed.
  • If the limb remains up on the table, a fixed flexion deformity at hip is suspected. Angle subtended between the thigh and the bed is the angle of flexion deformity.

Reference:Eseential orthopedics by Maheshwari 7thedition page no 341.
